title:
Lower bounds for the number of closed billiard trajectories of period 2
  and 3 in manifolds embedded in Euclidean space

title_detail.value:
Lower bounds for the number of closed billiard trajectories of period 2
  and 3 in manifolds embedded in Euclidean space

summary:
A lower bound for the number of 3-periodical billiard trajectories in a
manifold embedded in Euclidean space is obtained.

summary_detail.value:
A lower bound for the number of 3-periodical billiard trajectories in a
manifold embedded in Euclidean space is obtained.

author: Fedor Duzhin
fulltext:
arXiv:math/0112180v2 [math.AT] 30 Jan 2002

Lower bounds for the number of closed billiard
trajectories of period 2 and 3 in manifolds
embedded in Euclidean space
Fedor S. Duzhin
November 2001

1

Introduction

Let M be a smooth closed m-dimensional manifold embedded in Euclidean
space Rn . An ordered set (x1 , . . . , xp ) ∈ M × . . . × M is called a periodic
(closed) billiard trajectory if the condition
xi − xi+1
xi − xi−1
+

holds for each i ∈ Zp .
In this paper we find lower bounds for the number of closed billiard trajectories of periods 2 and 3 in an arbitrary manifold.

By RD p (M) we denote the reduced dihedric power of M, that is D p (M) with
the diagonal ∆ = ∆(p−2) contracted to a point.
It is well known that p-periodical billiard trajectories are the critical
points of the function f outside of ∆. Thus our problem is to estimate the
minimal number BTp (M) of critical points of the function l for all generic
embeddings of the manifold M in Euclidean space. Here we say that an embedding M → Rn is generic if the function l has only non-degenerate critical
points outside of ∆.
Recall the following facts:
Theorem (see [5]) Let p be a prime integer. Then
X
BTp (M) ≥
dim Hq (M ×p /Dp , ∆; Z2 ).
Theorem (M. Farber, S. Tabachnikov, [3], [4]) Let p be an odd prime.
Then
X
dim H̃q (RD p (S m ); Z2 ) = m(p − 1).

In this paper we estimate the number of closed billiard trajectories of
period 2 and 3 for an arbitrary manifold. The estimate for period 2 was
proved by P. Pushkar in [2], we give a new proof.

Theorem Let M be a smooth
Pm closed m-dimensional manifold. By B denote
the sum of Betti numbers q=0 dim Hq (M; Z2 ). Then we have the following
estimates for the number of periodical billiard trajectories:

A. Dold's theory of homology of symmetric
products

In this section we consider Z2 -modules.
Definition An FD-module K is a sequence of modules Kq , q = 0, 1, . . . and
module morphisms ∂qi : Kq → Kq−1 , siq : Kq → Kq+1 , i = 0, 1, . . .. The
morphisms ∂qi are called face operators, siq are called degeneracy operators.
The face- and degeneracy- operators satisfy the following axioms:
• ∂qi = 0, siq = 0 if i > q

Another way to define homology groups is as follows. The boundary operator is ∂q = ∂q0 −∂q1 +∂q2 −. . ., the qth homology group is Hq = ker ∂q / im ∂q+1 .
Denote this functor by R′ .
Proposition (A. Dold, [6])
1. There exists a functor R−1 from chain modules to FD-modules such
that RR−1 and R−1 R are naturally equivalent to the respective identity
functors.
3

 2. Let K be an FD-module. Chain modules R(K) and R′ (K) are homotopically equivalent and therefore they have isomorphic homology
groups.
3. The functor R moves homotopically equivalent FD-modules (to be defined later) to homotopically equivalent chain modules.
A morphism of FD-modules (or FD-morphism) i : K → K ′ is a set of
linear mappings iq : Kq → Kq′ such that iq−1 ∂ i = ∂ i iq and iq+1 si = si iq . A
morphism of FD-modules induces a homomorphism of homology groups i∗ .

We have constructed an FD-module K(X) of a topological space X.
Let x0 be a distinguished point of the space X. All simplices {f : ∆q →
x0 } form an FD-submodule pt(X) ⊂ K(X). The quotient K(X)/pt(X) is
called the reduced FD-module of a topological space X, its homology H̃∗ (X)
is the reduced homology of X. It is well known that H̃q (X) ∼
= Hq (X) if
q > 0, dim H0 (X) = dim H̃0 (X) + 1.
The continuous map f : X → Y induces an FD-morphism f# : K(X) →
K(Y ). The map f : (X, x0 ) → (Y, y0) of pointed spaces induces a morphism
of reduced FD-modules.
Now we define a direct product of FD-modules.

Now define an FD-module homotopy. First we construct an FD-module
K(n) that is usually called an FD-module of a standard n-simplex. The
group K(n)q is free generated by all sets of integers (w0 , w1 , . . . , wq ) such
that 0 ≤ w0 ≤ . . . ≤ wq ≤ n. Face- and degeneracy- operators are given by
the formulas
∂qi (w0 , . . . , wq ) = (w0 , . . . , wi−1 , wi+1 , . . . , wq ),
siq (w0 , . . . , wq ) = (w0 , . . . , wi , wi , . . . , wq ).
Let ei = (i) ∈ K(n)1 be an ith vertex.
Definition Suppose K ′ and K ′′ are FD-modules, F 0 , F 1 : K ′ → K ′′ are
FD-morphisms. An FD-homotopy is an FD-morphism Θ : K(1) × K ′ → K ′′
such that

Θ (s00 )q ei ⊗ aq = F i (aq ), aq ∈ Kq′ , i = 0, 1.

If there exists such homotopy Θ, then FD-morphisms F 0 and F 1 are called
homotopic, F 0 ∼ F 1 . If there exist FD-morphisms F + : K ′ → K ′′ and
F − : K ′′ → K ′ such that F + F − ∼ Id and F − F + ∼ Id, then FD-modules K ′
and K ′′ are called homotopically equivalent.
A. Dold has proved the following fact in [6]:

Theorem Two FD-modules are homotopically equivalent if and only if they
have isomorphic homology groups.
Let T be a functor on the category of FD-modules.
Definition The functor T preserves homotopy if T (F 0 ) ∼ T (F 1 ) for each
pair F 0 , F 1 of homotopic FD-morphisms.

5

 Theorem (A. Dold, [6]) Suppose the functor T preserves homotopy. Then
H∗ (K ′ ) ∼
= H∗ (T (K ′′ )),
= H∗ (K ′′ ) ⇒ H∗ (T (K ′ )) ∼
for each pair of FD-modules K ′ , K ′′ .
Let t be a functor on the category of Z2 -modules. Suppose K is an
FD-module. Put
T (K)q = t(Kq ), Fqi = t(∂qi ), Dqi = t(siq ).
Thus T (K) is an FD-module with face-operators Fqi and degeneracy-operators
Dqi . We say that the functor T is a prolongation of the functor t.
The pth direct product K ×p of an FD-module K is a simplest example of
a prolongation.
Theorem (A. Dold, [6]) Suppose the functor T is a prolongation of the
functor t. Then T preserves homotopy.
Now we can prove the following statement:
Lemma 2.1 Let M1 and M2 be polytopes. Then H∗ (M1 ; Z2 ) ∼
= H∗ (M2 ; Z2 )
implies
H∗ (M1 × M1 × M1 /D3 , ∆M1 ; Z2 ) ∼
= H∗ (M2 × M2 × M2 /D3 , ∆M2 ; Z2 ).
As above, the dihedral group D3 acts on M ×3 by permutations of factors,
∆M = {(x, x, y)} ⊂ M ×3 /D3 .
P r o o f. Suppose M is a triangulated subset of Euclidean space, x0 ∈ M
is a distinguished point. Thus (x0 , x0 , x0 ) is a distinguished point in the
Cartesian cube M ×3 . Let X = RD 3 (M) be the reduced dihedric cube of M.

 By Ksym denote the FD-submodule of K generated by all chains of the
form c1 ⊗ c2 ⊗ c3 + c2 ⊗ c3 ⊗ c1 , c1 ⊗ c2 ⊗ c3 + c2 ⊗ c1 ⊗ c3 , and c1 ⊗ c1 ⊗ c3 .
Let u : Ksym → K be the inclusion, φ : K → K/Ksym be the quotient
FD-morphism.
It follows from A. Dold's theorem that the homology H∗ (K/Ksym ) can
be computed if we know only the homology H∗ (M). Let us prove that
H∗ (K/Ksym ) ∼
= H∗ (K ′ ), this will complete the proof of the lemma.

that u(Ksym ) ⊂ ker p# .

Let us show that the FD-morphism α induces an isomorphism of homology groups. We will construct a triangulation τ of the space M ×3 . The idea
is as follows. This triangulation will be coherent with the filtration
{(x, x, x)} = D 0 ⊂ {(x, x, y), (x, y, x), (y, x, x)} = D ⊂ M × M × M
and invariant under the action of the dihedric group D3 . Since τ is invariant
up to the action of D3 , τ induces a triangulation τ /D3 of the space D 3 (M) =
M ×3 . Since the diagonal D is triangulated, τ /D3 induces a cell decomposition
p(τ ) of the space D 3 (M)/D3 . All affine maps f : ∆q → M ×3 such that f
moves vertices of ∆q to vertices of a simplex δ ∈ τ generate an FD-submodule
S ⊂ K. The image p# (S) = S ′ ⊂ K ′ is an FD-submodule of K ′ . By Ssym
we denote the intersection Ksym ∩ S. There are inclusions i : Ssym → Ksym
and j : S → K, hence there is an inclusion k : S/Ssym → K/Ksym . We show
all this FD-modules and morphisms on the following commutative diagram

In is well know that the inclusions j and l induce isomorphisms of homology groups. It is easy to see that i∗ is an isomorphism too. Indeed, suppose
we have a singular cycle ζ ∈ ker ∂q ⊂ (Ksym )q . Its 0-skeleton consists of the
points on the diagonal and pairs of symmetric points. Thus we can construct
a homotopy Ft of its 0-skeleton such that the image of Ft belongs to Ksym
for each t, and the image of F1 belongs to Ssym . Then we can extend Ft to
1-skeleton, and so on. Now two short exact sequences of FD-modules give
us two long sequences of homology groups. By the well known 5-lemma, it
follows that k∗ is an isomorphism.

Now we see that all elements of ker α have either simplices whose images intersect the diagonal or simplices whose images lie in the diagonal
and intersect the small diagonal. Clearly, it follows that ker α ∩ im k = 0.
Evidently, im α ◦ k = im l. We obtain that α ◦ k : S/Ssym → l(S ′ ) is an
FD-isomorphism. We see that l∗ , k∗ , l∗−1 ◦ (α ◦ k)∗ are isomorphisms. Consequently, α∗ = l∗ ◦ l∗−1 ◦ (α ◦ k)∗ ◦ k∗−1 is an isomorphism.
Now let us construct a triangulation of the space M ×3 . Suppose the
simplices Liq form a triangulation of the space M (here q is the dimension,
i is an index). Then the Cartesian cube M × M × M is divided into sets
Lq × Lq × Lq , Lq × Lq × Lr , and Lp × Lq × Lr (here p, q, r are all distinct).
First consider Lp × Lq × Lr . By τpqr denote any triangulation for Lp ×
Lq × Lr , p < q < r. Any triple p, q, r is a permutation of p′ < q ′ < r ′ , so a
triangulation for Lp × Lq × Lr is obtained by the action of D3 from τp′ q′ r′ .
Now consider Lq × Lq × Lq . There is a filtration
{(x, x, x)} = D 0 ⊂ {(x, x, y), (x, y, x), (y, x, x)} = D ⊂ Lq × Lq × Lq .
We triangulate Lq × Lq × Lq according to this filtration and action of the
group D3 . Suppose (x, y, z) ∈ ∆q × ∆q × ∆q . Let the faces of the simplex ∆q
have indices 0, 1, . . . , q. By Aa denote the distance from x to ath face, by B b
denote the distance from y to bth face, by C c denote the distance from z to
cth face, 1 ≤ a, b, c ≤ q.

and invariant under the action of the group D2 . We can do it in similar way

Lr . Now we see that for Lq × Lq × sk0 (Lr ) the triangulation is constructed.
Evidently, we can extend this triangulation from Lq × Lq × skj (Lr ) to Lq ×
Lq × skj+1 (Lr ).
This completes the proof. ✷

Proof of P. Pushkar's theorem

space Rn , kq = dim Hq (M; Z2 ). We need to calculate the sum

Let us construct a cell decomposition for each Api = RD 3 (S p ) like we have
done it for RD 2 (S p ). We consider a p-sphere as a p-dimensional cube [0, 1]×p
with the boundary contracted to a point. Let φ1i , φ2j , φ3k be the coordinates
on three such cubes. There are the following cells. First
Uβd = {φi11 ∗ φj11 ∗ φk11 , . . . , φimm ∗ φjmm ∗ φkmm },
where ∗ is one of the signs < or =, (iα , jα , kα) is a permutation of 1, 2, 3.
Secondly
Vβd = {φ11 ∗ φ21 , . . . , φ1m ∗ φ2m , φ
~ 3 = 0},
where ∗ is one of the signs <, >, =. Clearly, the cells of the kind U do not
belong to the boundaries of the cells of the kind V . Similarly, the cells of
17

evident for p > 1. For p = 1 all boundary operators here vanish.
We see that a chain complex for Api is a direct sum of two subcomplexes
u(Api ) and v(Api ).
